# Tracking budget bills and their changes

Bills proposed by the governor, necessary to implement the governor's proposed budget, are called budget bills. They include appropriation bills plus several bills that would change substantive law.

Budget bills go through several steps. Typical steps for recent years are:

-   **Submission**: The governor submits proposed legislation accompanying memos when she or he submits the budget. Initially the bills are in manuscript form (without a print number). They can be found on the Division of the Budget's web page, under a section on legislation. The archival page for fiscal year 2024 (i.e., 2023-24), is [here](https://www.budget.ny.gov/pubs/archive/fy24/ex/index.html); a more prominent page will be available for the current budget when it is released.

-   **Introduction**: The bills are introduced in each house as uni-bills (a Senate number and an Assembly number on the same document). They can now be found on the legislation pages of the [Senate](https://www.nysenate.gov/legislation) and the [Assembly](https://nyassembly.gov/leg/), and on other tracking sites. DOB may replace the manuscript versions on its web page with the printed versions.

-   **30-day amendments (A print)**: The governor may amend the budget bills when she or he submits the 30-day amendments. The bills will become B prints and remain uni-bills, identical in each house.

-   **One-house bills (B print)**: Each house stakes out its position by (1) adopting a budget resolution that summarizes how it proposes to amend the governor's budget - what it would modify, drop, or add, and (2) introducing legislation that would implement what the resolution specifies. In recent years, the Senate and Assembly have taken different approaches to their one-house resolutions: the Senate resolution summarizes all major changes it would make to the budget; by contrast, the Assembly resolution gives the bill numbers they would amend, without details, but releases a separate report detailing the changes they would make, explaining the changes, and giving estimates of their fiscal impact. The Senate and Assembly bills are NOT uni-bills or same-as bills - they differ from each other because they do not yet reflect agreement between the houses.

-   **Agreed-to budget bills (C print)**: After negotiations are complete, the Senate and Assembly print the agreed-to bills as uni-bills.

While this is a typical process, it could differ if, for example, a house prints multiple iterations of its position on the budget.

Tracking changes...

## Budget bills for the 2023-24 budget

-   [S4000](https://legislation.nysenate.gov/pdf/bills/2023/S4000)/[A3000](https://nyassembly.gov/leg/?bn=A03000&term=2023) State Operations Budget

-   [S4001](https://legislation.nysenate.gov/pdf/bills/2023/S4001)/[A3001](https://nyassembly.gov/leg/?bn=A03001&term=2023) Legislature and Judiciary Budget

-   [S4002](https://legislation.nysenate.gov/pdf/bills/2023/S4002)/[A3002](https://nyassembly.gov/leg/?bn=A03002&term=2023) Debt Service Fund -- General Debt Service Fund

-   [S4003](https://legislation.nysenate.gov/pdf/bills/2023/S4003)/[A3003](https://nyassembly.gov/leg/?bn=A03003&term=2023) Aid to Localities Budget

-   [S4004](https://legislation.nysenate.gov/pdf/bills/2023/S4004)/[A3004](https://nyassembly.gov/leg/?bn=A03004&term=2023) Capital Projects Budget

-   [S4005](https://legislation.nysenate.gov/pdf/bills/2023/S4005)/[A3005](https://nyassembly.gov/leg/?bn=A03005&term=2023) **Public protection and general government** budget bill

-   [S4006](https://legislation.nysenate.gov/pdf/bills/2023/S4006)/[A3006](https://nyassembly.gov/leg/?bn=A03006&term=2023) **Education, labor, housing and family assistance** budget bill

-   [S4007](https://legislation.nysenate.gov/pdf/bills/2023/S4007)/[A3007](https://nyassembly.gov/leg/?bn=A03007&term=2023) **Health and mental hygiene** budget bill

You can find the 30-day amendment versions at the same link, at top. Note that these links will change when the FY 2025 bills become available.
